awd_titl_txt: New Strategies for Creating Single and Dual Atom Catalysts on Silica Surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Catalysts allow reactions to proceed faster and to produce  greater quantities of desirable products.  Industrial chemistry would not be possible without the use of catalysts. However, big challenges remain regarding the sustainable use and recycling of catalysts. An optimal catalyst would consist of only one or two atoms that are prevented from grouping together and forming large bundles (aggregates). This separation of atoms can be achieved by arranging the atoms on a surface and retaining them at their specific surface sites. In this project, Professor Janet Bluemel of Texas A&M University is making use of two earlier discoveries to reach this goal. First, a well-defined one layer (monolayer) of metal complexes are placed on surfaces such as silica. The metal complexes are then modified to form single atoms that remain in place, dispersed on the surface. Similarly, two-atom assemblies are being prepared from metal complexes containing two different metal centers that are bound to the surface. Professor Bluemel's group is exploring the catalytic activities of these single- and dual-atom catalysts, their ability to form products selectively, and their recyclability. Different analytical approaches are being used and refined to obtain better insight into the surface processes and ultimately generate more efficient catalysts with superior characteristics. The project is enhancing the fundamental knowledge about how to create well-defined, efficient, recyclable catalysts in general and is leading to more sustainable processes. This project also provides broad, in-depth training for undergraduate and graduate students in Professor Bluemel's laboratory. In particular, the students are provided with opportunities for direct interaction with both domestic and international chemical companies, thus giving them unique and beneficial industrial experience.

With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Janet Bluemel of Texas A&M University is investigating dynamic processes on silica surfaces that involve supported molecular nickel, palladium, and copper complexes. The species are supported by tethering the complexes to the surface with the use of linkers. The tethered species are used as precursors to deliberately create well-defined single- and dual metal atom catalysts on surfaces such as silica. Dynamic processes do not occur only when covalently immobilized catalysts are suspended in a solvent. The Bluemel group has discovered that metal complexes adsorbed via Van der Waals interactions also display different modes of mobility on surfaces within pores, even in the absence of a solvent. At present there is a rudimentary understanding of how catalysts and their precursors diffuse in suspension or on dry surfaces. The ultimate goal of this project is to exploit the impact of specific tridentate phosphine linkers and the dry adsorption of nickelocene, which leads to well-defined monolayers, and to explore new methods for generating single- and dual atom catalysts (SACs, DACs) and well-defined nanoparticles on oxide surfaces. All approaches, which aim at stabilizing the metal particles and preventing their unrestricted growth are only feasible on surfaces. Investigating molecular immobilized and adsorbed catalyst precursors and the supported active metal catalysts generated from them, improves the understanding of their decomposition, agglomeration, and formation of metal particles. Direct insight regarding the structure and dynamics of all surface species is provided by High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy, dia- and paramagnetic 1H, 2H, 13C, 29Si, and 31P Magic Angle Spinning Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy of the dry materials and other techniques.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Overview: The objective of this project was to thoroughly investigate dynamic processes on silica surfaces that involve supported molecular nickel, palladium, and copper complexes and to use them as precursors to deliberately create well-defined molecular catalysts and metal single- and dual atom catalysts on silica surfaces. Dynamic processes do not only occur when catalysts immobilized covalently via linkers are suspended in a solvent. It has been discovered during this project that metal complexes adsorbed via van der Waals interactions can also display different modes of mobility on diverse surfaces within the pores, even in the absence of a solvent. The understanding about how catalysts and their precursors can travel in suspensions and on dry surfaces has been enhanced. Based on this knowledge, specific mono- and tridentate phosphine linkers have been immobilized on silica surfaces in well-defined monolayers. In this way, improved catalysts with reduced nanoparticle formation could be obtained. The principle has been demonstrated using rhodium hydrogenation catalysts and immobilized nickel catalysts for the cyclotrimerization of acetylenes, which could be recycled numerous times. As an alternative to covalent anchoring of metal complexes, the dry adsorption of nickelocene has been exploited to generate and characterize well-defined monolayers on silica. This research led to new methods for generating single- and dual atom catalysts (SAC, DAC) on surfaces. Additionally, it has been discovered that solid solutions of nickelocene with ferrocene can be created in the absence of a solvent. All approaches for immobilizing and stabilizing the metal complexes and particles are feasible on diverse surfaces.

Intellectual Merit: Investigating molecular immobilized and adsorbed catalyst precursors and the supported active metal catalysts generated from them, improved the understanding about their decomposition, agglomeration, and formation of metal particles. Direct insight regarding the structure and dynamics of all surface species was provided by HRTEM, dia- and paramagnetic 1H, 2H, 13C, 27Al, 29Si, and 31P MAS NMR of the dry materials and HRMAS in the presence of solvents. All NMR techniques needed for the characterization have been further developed and refined.  

          Molecular mono-, di- and trinuclear nickel, palladium, and copper catalysts have been immobilized via mono- and tridentate phosphine linkers. The tridentate phosphines also produced caged Pd3 assemblies that were tested for catalysis. The hydrogenation of olefins, the cyclotrimerization of acetylenes, and Sonogashira C-C coupling reactions have been utilized to study the catalytic selectivities and activities of the immobilized catalysts. Additionally, nickelocene has been self-adsorbed onto favorable support surfaces in monolayers and transformed into a SAC by mild reduction with hydrogen. The observed dynamic processes of all catalyst precursors have been correlated with the structures and compositions, selectivities, and activities of the catalysts on the silica surface. Different analytical approaches have been refined to obtain better insight and ultimately generate more efficient catalysts with superior characteristics. The project enhanced the fundamental knowledge about how to create well-defined, atom-efficient, recyclable, supported catalysts in general and led to more sustainable processes.

Broader Impact of the Project: This experimentally and analytically diverse project provided broad, in-depth training for numerous undergraduate and graduate students. The students worked in such far-ranging areas as preparative organic and organometallic chemistry, homogeneous and solid/liquid biphase catalysis, surface chemistry, and solid-state NMR. The unique research opportunities allowed all students to develop their own creative ideas, and they presented their results as posters and oral contributions at local and national meetings. The PI's group hosted several undergraduate REU students. The PI has also established an interdisciplinary network of colleagues at Texas A&M (Engineering), and could continue existing and start new collaborations with industry (Lynntech, Hoerbiger, Albemarle) during the project. Therefore, the PI's students experienced first-hand the translation of their results into industrial applications. Many publications in high-ranking journals additionally enhanced the visibility of the research performed for the project. Most importantly, being able to render catalytic processes more sustainable will help to cope with the increasing materials and energy demands of the modern world. 

 


Last Modified: 12/20/2023
Modified by: Janet Bluemel
